learning_outcomes.description: Understand the foundations of evidence-based therapy and demonstrate knowledge of core principles in psychological interventions, that include face to face and digital applications
Develop therapeutic skills and apply foundational therapeutic strategies in practice
Perform psychological risk assessments: assess and manage suicide risk and other psychological risks effectively.
Develop structured case formulations and treatment plans using evidence-based principles
Engage in self-reflection for professional practice and self-care
Apply culturally responsive practices in their work with clients from culturally and linguistically diverse and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds.

assessments.task_description: Students will conduct and record a 15-20 minute role-play intake interview with a peer acting as the client, demonstrating competency in foundational microskills and intake procedures including establishing rapport, discussing confidentiality, exploring presenting concerns, and summarising key information. Following the interview, students will complete a self-evaluation using the Interview Checklist (available on learn.uq) and submit a brief written reflection identifying strengths, areas for development, and aspects they found challenging. A one-page dot-point summary of peer feedback received must also be included. This assessment develops practical interviewing skills alongside capacity for self-reflection and integration of feedback.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission is via Blackboard. If required, there are videoing facilities within the UQ Psychology Clinic consult rooms.

assessments.task_description: This is a competency-based assessment for conducting a suicide and safety risk assessment role-play with a simulated client presenting with suicide risk factors. The assessment evaluates the student's ability to explore suicidal ideation, identify protective and risk factors, determine level of risk, and collaboratively develop an appropriate safety plan. Following the role-play, students will complete a written formulation, plan, and a reflection on performance. Individual timeslots (40 minutes) will be allocated to each student.

assessments.category: Practical/ Demonstration, Presentation, Reflection, Role play/ Simulation
assessments.task_description:
This is a two-part competency-based assessment. 


Part 1: Students will be presented with a case study and required to demonstrate an appropriate CBT skill (allocated in role-play) with a simulated client. Following the role-play, students will be asked to verbally reflect on their performance.


 Part 2: Following the in-person role-play and reflections, students will be able to take home their notes and are required to write a case-note, as one might to do in practice, including a session note, a formulation, and a treatment plan moving forward. The students will then be asked a series of questions for student's to demonstrate their clinical reasoning (provided ahead of time via learn.uq). This is required to be submitted via Turn-it-in 48 hours after completion of their role-play.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The written component is to be submitted via the Assessment page on learn.uq.

assessments.task_description: Students are required to complete a worksheet that outlines a therapy skill learnt in class, and asked to provide a reflection on the therapy skills completed on the worksheet and practiced in class. The worksheet and reflections will be submitted the following week via Assessment Page on learn.uq. The final self-reflection piece is worth 15% and requires students to reflect on their therapies skill with regard to professional competencies for psychologists, with a particular focus on digital health, culturally responsive practices in their work with clients from culturally and linguistically diverse and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds, and trauma-informed care.
